newsitem.title: USA: NYMEX Hub natgas ends with gains, still in range.
newsitem.headline: NYMEX Hub natgas ends with gains, still in range.

text.p: NYMEX Henry Hub natgas futures ended with modest gains late Friday in sluggish trade, lifted by reports of steady to firmer weekend cash prices in the face of more below-normal weather early next week.
May climbed 3.3 cents to close at $1.933 per million British thermal units. June settled 2.8 cent higher at $1.995. Other deferreds ended up by one to 3.5 cents.

"We were under pressure much of the day, but they (short) covered up for the weekend. I don't think you can read much into today's action," said one East Coast trader, noting prices were still bound in recent technical ranges.

While traders said favorable spreads and cold weather early next week could support prices near-term, they said bloated storage, particularly in the East, left buyers with plenty of leverage to limit the upside.
Forecasters were looking for more below-normal Midwest and eastern weather early next week though more seasonal temperatures were predicted later in the week.
Chart traders still pegged May trendline support at $1.88, with better buying likely at $1.85 and $1.825. Resistance remained at $2 and then at $2.045-2.05 and $2.10.

In the cash, Gulf Coast prices were talked up a few cents Friday to the mid-$1.90s or better. Midcontinent pipes scored similar gains to the mid-$1.80s. Weekend gas at the New York city gate was talked down a few cents to the $2.35-2.40 area.
The NYMEX Henry Hub 12-month strip rose 2.4 cents to $2.134. NYMEX said 22,161 Hub contracts traded, down slightly from Thursday's revised tally of 24,748.
No Permian or Alberta natgas contracts traded Friday.

On the KCBT, May finished 2.9 cents higher at $1.799, while deferreds ended up by one-half to 2.5 cents. The East/West spread widened by 0.4 cent to 13.4 cents (NYMEX premium). KCBT said 92 lots changed hands, up from Thursday's total of 86.
